subject: RE: [nihontostudy] shinsa question
msgSnippet: Ron, I have thought about this alot and only recently have come to a conclusion.  Given my desire for only mantis themed items, I couldn t decide to mount them

Subject: RE: [nihontostudy] shinsa question
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=125654407
X-Yahoo-Profile: kdw21620

Ron,

I have thought about this alot and only recently have
come to a conclusion.  Given my desire for only mantis
themed items, I couldn't decide to mount them or not
(one day when I do remount a sword or 2).  I came to
the conclusion that I enjoy seeing all these items
grouped together in my display table and having them
all together makes them available for quick study.  I
therefore decided not to mount them (my mantis items).
 On the other hand I decided when I do remount some
swords, that I may choose a secondary theme like
fishing (other passion of mine) to mount in.  I may
also just opt for just a shirasaya but have recently
been leaning toward a bit nicer of a display (matching
fittings, handle wrap, etc).  When I view my items it
is usually just the swords or just fittings, depends
on my mood.  I also know that I am unique in that I
collect 1 theme, although there are many others like
me out there.  However, if I were to find a sword with
all mantis fittings,  I would keep it together.  1
tsuba on a sword would most likely be stripped and
replaced with something else, especially if I didn't
have that tsuba school represented.  I wonder if guys
into iado/ sword practitioners or musuem guys (Gordon)
view the whole package ,sword, fittings, saya, etc as
one, while I tend to view it in terms of seperate
entities.  I'm rambling here so I'll stop.  It all
comes down to Personal preference- no right or wrong.

Ken


--- Gordon Robson <robsongo@...> wrote:
> Although I am sure to take some heat for this, my
> feelings have always been
> that mounts belong on swords and not in boxes.
> However, there are mounts and
> then there are swords and they should be at the same
> level if put together.
> Still, your approach is often taken everywhere,
> including Japan.
> 
>  
> 
> Gordon
> 
>  
> 
> -----Original Message-----
> From: Ron Hartmann [mailto:swords@...] 
> Sent: Wednesday, January 21, 2004 2:55 AM
> To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] shinsa question
> 
>  
> 
> Gordon - 
> 
> A personal dilemma. Last March I've purchased a
> beautiful mumei katana with
> fantastic (really!) horimono. It came with koshirae
> which had damage. I've
> had the sword put into shirazaya and a tsunagi made
> for the koshirae with
> repairs, on-going. Because the tsuka wrapping was
> literally falling apart,
> the fuchi/kashira and menuki were removed and
> therefore, able to be examined
> in-hand. The menuki are solid gold "dragons" which
> are super! The
> fuchi/kashira (mumei) are even more fine and really
> do cry for shinsa with
> an eye toward Goto. The kozuka/kogai looked
> "mainline Goto" but drew
> (reportedly) a generic "Goto den" call from the
> NBTHK. 
> 
> My dilemma, should these wonderful fitting be placed
> back on the sword or be
> kept seperately and "boxed" for individual
> preservation and appreciation. I
> say "dilemma" but in all honesty my choice has been
> made; they will be boxed
> for individual in-hand appreciation. So, should I
> feel bad to have in a
> sense "destroyed" a koshirae or should I feel good
> to have discovered these
> wonderful kodogu. Granted, the koshirae was not
> truly a (and I hate this
> expression) "matching" koshirae and was really "put
> together" by it pre-war
> owner. Yes, I'll keep the saya and (unmounted) tsuka
> together with a tsunagi
> but it seems such a waste to put these beautiful
> fitting back on it where
> they can be damaged (f/k, kozuka/kogai) or hidden
> under ito (menuki). 
> 
> After saying all this I'm not too sure where I'm
> going with it, but my point
> might be that there is a time to "preserve" a
> koshirae" and a time to not
> worry about it. 
> 
> Ron
> STL
>   ----- Original Message ----- 
>   From: Gordon Robson 
>   To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com 
>   Sent: Monday, January 19, 2004 8:18 PM
>   Subject: RE: [nihontostudy] shinsa question
> 
> 
>   I think if you look at museum collections in
> Japan, the answer is there.
>   They do not touch anything no matter the
> condition. If the wrap is coming
>   off, it is coming off. They may add something to
> secure menuki and such to
>   keep them in place - typically thread. The same
> goes with lacquer, it is
> not
>   touched. Thus, the standards for shinsa are the
> same. I am pretty sure
> this
>   is the case with the NBTHK as well. So, what to do
> to repair something? If
>   you want to keep the piece original and unaltered,
> you must have all new
>   mounts made and you set aside the original pieces.
> I know this may seem to
>   be unreasonable, but those are the very high
> standards that have been
>   maintained at shinsa and in museums. I think the
> same holds true for
> antique
>   firearms. Re-blued barrels, re-done stocks and
> what not seriously harm the
>   value of the piece. Thus, such alterations should
> not be done lightly.
> 
> 
> 
>   Jim, care to comment?
> 
> 
> 
>   Gordon
> 
> 
> 
>   -----Original Message-----
>   From: samurai@... [mailto:samurai@...]
> 
>   Sent: Tuesday, January 20, 2004 12:03 PM
>   To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
>   Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] shinsa question
> 
> 
> 
>   <robsongo@...> writes:
> 
>   > Hi Cary and Milt,
>   > This is good timing as I wanted to warn Chicago
> shinsa attendees about
>   > submitting koshirae. If you submit a tsuka, then
> the same will apply as
>   with
>   > the NBTHK. Make sure that the tsuka has not been
> re-wrapped in the last
>   100
>   > or so years - that means it is no longer antique
> and will be bounced.
>   Entire
>   > koshirae will be judged based on authenticity
> and age of all the pieces,
>   > i.e. nothing replaced, re-wrapped or
> re-lacquered. Also, if pieces are
>   > mumei, they will not be attributed. You must
> submit the pieces
> separately
>   > for that. If all or some of the pieces are
> signed, then they will be
>   > authenticated. 
> 
>   In the case of damaged koshirae, is this a
> bouncable offense, in which
>   case once something is damaged it becomes
> unpaperable?
> 
>   - darcy
> 
>
